importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the four members of the Luna family were murdered in Phoenix, marking the timeline of the crime that led to Richard Kenneth Djerf's execution.
The date of Djerf's execution, which is significant as it is the second execution in Arizona that year and part of a broader national context of executions in the U.S. during the month.
The year executions resumed in Arizona after a pause due to concerns over the death penalty protocol and drug availability.
The year in which executions were paused again due to a review initiated by Governor Katie Hobbs, reflecting political and ethical scrutiny of capital punishment.
The end date of the review into Arizona's execution protocols, after which changes were implemented in the lethal injection team and procedures.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period marks the resumption and continuation of executions in Arizona after a hiatus, highlighting ongoing controversy and operational challenges in carrying out the death penalty.
This timeframe includes the pause in executions due to concerns over botched procedures and drug access, showing a pattern of public and political scrutiny over the death penalty in Arizona.

keyTakeAways: Richard Kenneth Djerf was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 murder of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix, including two children.
The execution was the second in Arizona that year and the fourth in the U.S. during the week, underscoring the national trend of ongoing death penalty enforcement.
Djerf was convicted of sexually assaulting and killing family members after blaming Albert Luna Jr. for a previous theft, indicating a motive rooted in revenge and obsession.
The execution process took about 10 minutes to complete, with Djerf's veins described as suboptimal, raising concerns about the efficiency and human cost of lethal injection procedures.
Arizona has faced criticism for past botched executions, including a 2014 case where a prisoner received 15 doses of drugs over two hours, showing deep procedural and ethical issues.
The state paused executions twice since 2014, reflecting political and public debate over the morality, efficiency, and fairness of capital punishment.
The execution of Djerf marks the 39th execution of the year in the U.S. and increases Arizona’s death row count to 107.
The death penalty in Arizona has been subject to significant internal review, with policy shifts and changes to execution teams occurring in 2023 and 2024.
No victims’ representatives were present during the execution, which raises questions about closure and public accountability in capital punishment cases.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A man convicted of murdering four members of a Phoenix family in 1993; executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in the article, the convicted murderer whose execution is the main event being reported.

namedEntities.name: Albert Luna Sr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A member of the Luna family murdered in 1993 at their Phoenix home.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the four victims whose death is central to the crime and the motivation behind the execution.

namedEntities.name: Patricia Luna
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A member of the Luna family murdered in 1993 at their Phoenix home.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the four victims whose death is central to the crime and the motivation behind the execution.

namedEntities.name: Rochelle Luna
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An 18-year-old daughter of the Luna family, murdered in 1993.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A victim of a sexual assault and murder, representing the tragic loss of a young life in the case.

namedEntities.name: Damien Luna
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 5-year-old son of the Luna family, murdered in 1993.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A child victim, emphasizing the brutality and heinous nature of the crime, which has drawn public attention.

namedEntities.name: Albert Luna Jr.
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A family member not present during the killings, who was blamed by Djerf for a prior theft.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as the alleged motive behind the revenge killings, illustrating a false narrative used to justify violence.

namedEntities.name: Arizona

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The jurisdiction where the crime occurred and where the execution took place, highlighting state-level policies on capital punishment.

namedEntities.name: Phoenix
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The city in Arizona where the murder of the Luna family occurred in 1993.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The geographic location of the crime, anchoring the case in a specific urban and regional context.

namedEntities.name: Kris Mayes
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Arizona Attorney General who sought the execution of Richard Kenneth Djerf.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A key public official advocating for the death penalty in this case, representing the state’s legal stance on capital punishment.

namedEntities.name: Joseph Wood
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A previous prisoner executed in Arizona in 2014, whose execution was botched and criticized.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as a precedent for past procedural failures that led to public criticism and policy pauses in executions.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Brian Gunches
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The last prisoner executed in Arizona prior to Djerf, killed in 2002 for the murder of Ted Price.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides context for the timeline of executions in Arizona, showing a history of death row activity.

namedEntities.name: Katie Hobbs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Democratic Governor of Arizona who paused executions in 2023 and ordered a review of capital punishment protocols.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A political figure whose actions influenced policy changes and pauses in capital punishment in Arizona.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A national organization that tracks the number of executions in the U.S.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides context by noting that five more executions are scheduled nationally in 2025, indicating broader national trends.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a significant execution event, Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was put to death in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 murder of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix—Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, 18-year-old Rochelle Luna, and 5-year-old Damien Luna—after being driven by a motive of revenge over a previous theft allegedly committed by Albert Luna Jr. The execution, the second in Arizona that year and the fourth in the U.S. that week, followed years of criticism and procedural failures, including a botched 2014 execution and multiple pauses since 2014. Despite Djerf's prior statement acknowledging the killings and apologizing, no victims' representatives were present. The process took about 10 minutes, with difficulties in IV placement due to poor vein conditions, and the execution raised concerns about the ethics and efficiency of lethal injection. With the case, Arizona’s death row total rose to 107, and the state continues to face political and public scrutiny over its death penalty practices.
title: Arizona Executes Man for Killing 4 Members of a Phoenix Family in 1993
